content.raw:
Any reason why I'm not on this pull request as a reviewer? bitbucket is supposed to be adding myself and Chris as reviewers by default now.

Couple of comments:

1. The channel label on each plot has moved. It's current position seems to make it appear like it belongs to the trace above it. Any reason why it can't stay on the side like it was before?
2. I'm not sure I like not having the time axis on every plot. It makes it harder to observe the quantisation of a trace when you zoom right in. 
3. Have you considered using [`pyqtgraph.InfiniteLine`](http://www.pyqtgraph.org/documentation/graphicsItems/infiniteline.html). I'm not sure what benefits it would bring (you can set them as non-movable so ignore the stuff in the docs about them being movable). Just thought I'd mention it in case you hadn't seen it and there was some benefit.
4. It looks like you've disabled scaling of the y axis in each plot. I'm not sure why? That effectively prevents you from ever looking closely at small amplitude features.
5. I should have realised this earlier, but the "markers" can have colours. This made sense when we were talking about showing coloured labels in BLACS, but I'm not sure how it fits in with the colours of the traces in runviewer, and how it works when you have multiple plots shown (which I assume you can still do?). Maybe we need to settle on a scheme like solid vertical line matching colour of trace with dots that match the colour of the marker, or we ignore the marker colour in runviewer
6. what happens if multiple shots have markers at the same time, but with different names/labels? We should probably stagger the labels at least?
7. It might make sense to put the markers plot widget outside of the scrollable area so the labels can always be seen.

I might have more comments once I actually test the software. These were just from reading the code :)
content.html:
Any reason why I'm not on this pull request as a reviewer? bitbucket is supposed to be adding myself and Chris as reviewers by default now.

Couple of comments:

  1. The channel label on each plot has moved. It's current position seems to make it appear like it belongs to the trace above it. Any reason why it can't stay on the side like it was before?
  2. I'm not sure I like not having the time axis on every plot. It makes it harder to observe the quantisation of a trace when you zoom right in.
  3. Have you considered using pyqtgraph.InfiniteLine. I'm not sure what benefits it would bring (you can set them as non-movable so ignore the stuff in the docs about them being movable). Just thought I'd mention it in case you hadn't seen it and there was some benefit.
  4. It looks like you've disabled scaling of the y axis in each plot. I'm not sure why? That effectively prevents you from ever looking closely at small amplitude features.
  5. I should have realised this earlier, but the "markers" can have colours. This made sense when we were talking about showing coloured labels in BLACS, but I'm not sure how it fits in with the colours of the traces in runviewer, and how it works when you have multiple plots shown (which I assume you can still do?). Maybe we need to settle on a scheme like solid vertical line matching colour of trace with dots that match the colour of the marker, or we ignore the marker colour in runviewer
  6. what happens if multiple shots have markers at the same time, but with different names/labels? We should probably stagger the labels at least?
  7. It might make sense to put the markers plot widget outside of the scrollable area so the labels can always be seen.

I might have more comments once I actually test the software. These were just from reading the code :)

content.raw:
1. This slipped in and I'll change it back. We did this to allow for smaller plot  and even smaller plots for digital outputs(also changed the ticks 1 to Hi and 0 to Lo) in our implementation. The labels quickly became bigger than the plots themselves and thats why we moved them.
2. Well not really as there is now a tool tip when moving the mouse over the plot with the current time
3. addLine does nothing but create a InfiniteLine and add it to the plot([see doc](http://www.pyqtgraph.org/documentation/graphicsItems/plotitem.html)). So I guess I'm already using InfiniteLine
4. This must have slipped in from our Implementation. We disabled y axis because we use runviewer mostly to check if timing in right and not the y-values. If it's a dealbreaker to rightclick and reenable y-axis for plots that need it I can change it back.
5. Yes multiple Plots are possible. If you load shots with different markers they are all treated in the same way.
6. They get overwritten. I didn't think of this case as we only view one shot at a time in our lab(because of nonlinear time). I'll think about how this can be done in a good way without having duplicates of the same label.
7. Sounds good but not sure how to do this in a way that keeps them aligned with everything else. I'll do some testing.
content.html:
1. This slipped in and I'll change it back. We did this to allow for smaller plot and even smaller plots for digital outputs(also changed the ticks 1 to Hi and 0 to Lo) in our implementation. The labels quickly became bigger than the plots themselves and thats why we moved them.
  2. Well not really as there is now a tool tip when moving the mouse over the plot with the current time
  3. addLine does nothing but create a InfiniteLine and add it to the plot(see doc). So I guess I'm already using InfiniteLine
  4. This must have slipped in from our Implementation. We disabled y axis because we use runviewer mostly to check if timing in right and not the y-values. If it's a dealbreaker to rightclick and reenable y-axis for plots that need it I can change it back.
  5. Yes multiple Plots are possible. If you load shots with different markers they are all treated in the same way.
  6. They get overwritten. I didn't think of this case as we only view one shot at a time in our lab(because of nonlinear time). I'll think about how this can be done in a good way without having duplicates of the same label.
  7. Sounds good but not sure how to do this in a way that keeps them aligned with everything else. I'll do some testing.

content.raw:
Ok so I have a new idea: We could add a drop down menu where one can select from the currently ticked shots which markers are to be shown. This would solve the coloring problem as markers would not mix from different shots. Also things would be less crowded and we could attach the non linear time to be calculated from those markers. This would make non linear mode work with multiple shots. 
I think I'll change the pull request to do this in the next few days.
content.html: Ok so I have a new idea: We could add a drop down menu where one can select from the currently ticked shots which markers are to be shown. This would solve the coloring problem as markers would not mix from different shots. Also things would be less crowded and we could attach the non linear time to be calculated from those markers. This would make non linear mode work with multiple shots. I think I'll change the pull request to do this in the next few days.

content.raw: If anyone wants to try out non linear time, shutters lines, markers, time tooltip and smaller digital plots I have a [branch](#!/PhyNerd/runviewer/branch/APQ) with all those features integrated.

content.raw:
I've just had a look at this, as I'm interested in getting the nonlinear time functionality working. Note that I have only been looking at the tip of this branch, as it seemed nontrivial to merge in the newer updates in the default branch.
A few suggestions before this is merged in:

* The y-axis scaling is turned off by default. Given that your lab likes to have this disabled, perhaps it would be convenient to have a button at the top of the interface which can switch y-scaling on and off globally. For ease of use, this should be set so that it overrides the current values if individual graphs have been manually enabled/disabled, rather than just inverting the current state.
* When scaling the y-axis of the top figure, I got a little confused at first, as there is no clear border between the region at the top with the labels, and the plotting region. This could be made more pleasing to the eye by either
    * Adding whitespace below the marker label region about the same size as the vertical gap between graphs, including a break in the marker lines (my preferred option)
    * shading the top marker label region grey
    * or adding a horizontal line across bottom of the marker label region.
* The vertical line in the marker label region where the y-axis would be doesn't quite line up with the other y-axes. This is not important, but it is annoying me!

The attached image shows the y-axis alignment issue and the vertical clipping on the top plot.

![runviewer_markers.PNG](data/bitbucket.org/repo/AeyynE/images/1388837391-runviewer_markers.PNG)
content.html:
I've just had a look at this, as I'm interested in getting the nonlinear time functionality working. Note that I have only been looking at the tip of this branch, as it seemed nontrivial to merge in the newer updates in the default branch. A few suggestions before this is merged in:

  • The y-axis scaling is turned off by default. Given that your lab likes to have this disabled, perhaps it would be convenient to have a button at the top of the interface which can switch y-scaling on and off globally. For ease of use, this should be set so that it overrides the current values if individual graphs have been manually enabled/disabled, rather than just inverting the current state.
  • When scaling the y-axis of the top figure, I got a little confused at first, as there is no clear border between the region at the top with the labels, and the plotting region. This could be made more pleasing to the eye by either
    • Adding whitespace below the marker label region about the same size as the vertical gap between graphs, including a break in the marker lines (my preferred option)
    • shading the top marker label region grey
    • or adding a horizontal line across bottom of the marker label region.
  • The vertical line in the marker label region where the y-axis would be doesn't quite line up with the other y-axes. This is not important, but it is annoying me!

The attached image shows the y-axis alignment issue and the vertical clipping on the top plot.

content.raw:
Didn't see these merge conflicts until now. I'm not sure when I will have time to adjust the code.  
As for the other comments:

* Yeah we find the y-axis scrolling really annoying. It keeps you from scrolling through a long list of channels. I'll readd it later today and maybe create a pull request with a button in the next few days.
* I probably need to rework that part of the code anyway. In order to allways display the plot and keep it from scrolling I had to do a bit of nasty hacking. This is also the reason for the misalignment of the y-axes. I'll look into moving the marker plot to It's own widget just above the plot area. That would probably solve a lot of the problems.

‌

The markers plot still has slight alignment issues (the marker lines in the top widget are showing up slightly offset from the lines in the plots), however the basic functionality appears to be complete.
I think in the interest of making progress on other issues such as nonlinear time, we should merge this now and fix the minor cosmetic issues in a later pull request.
